description:
Ripple Greenway is a beautiful 14-acre linear park and art trail.  Home to Katy Hallett’s steel sculptures, inspired by Robert Macfarlane’s and Jackie Morris’ The Lost Words.
Wooden play and exercise equipment, picnic tables and benches.

factsheet.heading: Transforming derelict land into a beautiful park
paragraphs: Walking and cycling charity, Sustrans, worked with funders, the Greater London Authority, the local community, the London Borough of Barking and Dagenham, Trees for Cities and other partners to transform a disused strip of land into a beautiful 14 acre linear park.

Now called the Ripple Greenway, it provides a 1.3km traffic-free route to school and work for thousands of people who live in the area. It is also a destination park where you can just sit and enjoy being outdoors.
Ripple Greenway is also now home to arresting steel sculptures by artist Katy Hallett. The works are inspired by Robert Macfarlane’s and Jackie Morris’ book, The Lost Words.

factsheet.heading: The origins of the idea for the Ripple Greenway
paragraphs: The idea for the greenway came from local residents who wanted to improve access to this underused greenspace. It was overgrown and uncared for. The majority of residents felt it was unsafe to use. Thirty-four percent of the borough’s surface has greenspace coverage, but within Thames Ward where Ripple Greenway is located, half the residents did not have good access to quality greenspace.

factsheet.heading: Linking existing and new communities
paragraphs: The park celebrates natural heritage and brings together the 1950s-established Thames View community with the emerging Barking Riverside development where 10,000 new homes, four new schools and a new Overground station are being built.

factsheet.heading: Bringing nature and art to people’s doorsteps
paragraphs: Ripple Greenway is now home to fantastic steel sculptures by artist Katy Hallett. The works are inspired by Robert Macfarlane’s and Jackie Morris’ book, The Lost Words.

Robert Macfarlane wrote a new poem for the Ripple Greenway which references the hundreds of trees planted by local residents and Trees for Cities. You can hear him read his poem and take a bird’s eye view of the Ripple Greenway on Sustrans’ YouTube channel and search Ripple Greenway. https://bit.ly/2TDmzAx

factsheet.heading: Using natural materials
paragraphs: The Greenway is now an accessible destination with a smooth path and natural 'play on the way' features. These include a group swing, reclaimed oak climbing logs and exercise equipment. There are also oak picnic tables and benches as well as memorial benches along the paths.

factsheet.heading: Increasing biodiversity
paragraphs: A large part of the Greenway design was about creating habitat where wildlife would flourish. Sustrans worked in collaboration with Trees for Cities to sow meadows, plant 115 trees and 2km of whip hedgerow. Bird and bat boxes, along with ecologically-sensitive lighting have also been installed.

factsheet.heading: Equality of access to greenspace
paragraphs: Injustice is at the heart of greenspace deprivation. Almost 40% of people of ethnic minority backgrounds live in England’s most greenspace-deprived neighbourhoods, compared with 14% of white people.

Sustrans worked with people whose voices often go unheard. These voices include people from ethnic minorities and disabled people. They were critical to the success of the design and delivery of a high-quality greenspace where people would feel comfortable to cycle, walk, use a pushchair or travel by wheelchair without the need for a car.

factsheet.heading: A lifeline for mental and physical wellbeing
paragraphs: During the pandemic, residents told us that the Greenway became a lifeline for wellbeing.
Doris, a resident since 1957, said: "I’ve finally got somewhere to go for a quiet stroll."
Quincy, a resident for 12 years, said: "I never used to come here, it didn’t feel safe. Now everyone comes here - you have brought this place to life."

factsheet.heading: A well used path
paragraphs: The path was completed in December 2019 and since February 2020, there have been almost 240,000 visits.
If every visitor travelled the length of the Ripple Greenway, they would have travelled a combined total of just under 310,000km – that’s over 7.5 times around the World.
Comparing June 2019 to June 2021, there has been a 13% increase in daily walking trips and a 171% increase in cycle trips.

factsheet.heading: Exemplar design for public space
paragraphs: We hope this wildlife restoration and habitat creation will set a benchmark for sustainable and nature-based public realm design in London.

Ripple Greenway is now a place of beauty that is accessible to everyone whether they walk, use a wheelchair, pushchair or cycle for everyday journeys. This was a place many people didn’t want to visit. It is now transformed into a welcoming place for everyone.

factsheet.heading: Working in partnership
paragraphs: The creation of the Ripple Greenway is the perfect example of what is possible when people and organisations come together and make something beautiful that many people can enjoy now and for generations to come.

Partners include the London Borough of Barking and Dagenham, Trees for Cities, Greater London Authority, local residents, London Borough of Barking and Dagenham Access Group, University of East London’s ecology department, Barking and Riverside Housing Association, Alexandra Steed URBAN, poet, Robert Macfarlane, sculptor, Katie Hallett, Thames View Infant School, Thames View Junior School, George Carey Primary School, Residents’ associations, Mums on a Mission, Thames View Muslim Association, Thames View Community Garden.
